content.description: Climb up the blocky cleft to the find hand crack that starts 30 feet off the ground. Follow the crack for 15 feet and finish beneath the cedar branch.

climbs.name: TLC
climbs.fa: Tom Patterson and Jim and Clif Lingenfelter (TR, 1989)

content.description: Generous pockets and a few strategic face holds are spaced just right to stay on the "fun" side of the line.
content.location: This climb stays on the left face of Diabolical Dihedral all the way to the top.

content.description: Follow the dihedral to the top. Surprisingly solid rock. The route passes behind a cedar tree halfway up.
content.location: The blocky dihedral just right of Buzz Off

content.description: A slightly overhanging face with several fine, roomy pockets. The only problem is that the pockets are just far enough apart to be brutal.
content.location: 30 feet north of diabolical dihedral, and a few feet left of the gravel-filled off-width.

content.description: In the center of the wall is a yellow nose pointing Southwest. Climb the face just below this nose, and then tackle the nose itself.
content.location: the left climb on the small wall just south and uphill from the main wall.

content.description: Another hard face climb. The face overhangs, the pockets are small, and the footwork is dubious at best.

Climb up and left on a ramp. When you reach the dead end in the yellow, overhanging dihedral, traverse right on a small horizontal ledge to the center of a smooth face. Using and undercling and a very long reach, continue up the face to ledge holds and pockets with a mantel to the top.
content.location: See picture. 5 feet left of Decapitator.

content.description: Follow a small double-crack dihedral for 25 feet to an overhang. Dodge around the bulge on the left, and climb up 10 feet to a ledge. From the ledge, follow a seam directly above the lower crack to the top.
content.location: See picture. Roughly in the center of the face.

content.description: It starts with pockets and works left slightly up into the overhang. The overhang about halfway up requires interesting maneuvers and a little bit of power. great face climbing on good pockets and crimps. Quite a bit of pump near the top as you traverse to the same end as Nutcracker.
content.location: Just to the left of Buzz Off and right of Nutcracker on the mostly blank face.Â

content.description: Climb straight up the center of the face.
content.location: See pic. Center of the south face.

content.description: Climb 15 feet to the crumbly ledge. Follow the dihedral to the top.
content.location: See picture. The large, blocky dihedral.

content.description: Stay out of the depths of the chimney by stemming across the opening. Avoid the huge hanging blade that gives the climb its name.
content.location: The large, block-filled chimney near the right edge of the wall.

content.description: Climb 10 feet into a seam, that opens up into a dihedral. When that gets too tough, step right around the corner.
content.location: See Picture. The whitest nose on the buttress, at the right edge of Bee Wall.

content.description: Double-shallow-roof route at the north end of the wall.
content.location: See picture. Just along the rail from Indian Head is a tall, crumbly monolith. Directly behind this outcrop is Bee Wall, and the Bee Line is the prominent double roof on the upper wall. The lower roof iw about 2 feet deep, and the upper roof is about a foot deep. There's a cedar at the top.

content.description: Climb up to the lone bush on this ramp, and then take the hand crack up to the cedar.
content.location: In between the prominent roofs of Six Hairy Legs and Four Wings and Fly, is a rubble-covered, low-angle nose.

content.description: Exposed, tall portion of the main rock wall between Indian Head and the Amphitheater.
